Logically, they should be safe in this alternate space. After all, breaking the fragile glass on the watch face would immediately teleport them out. Even if someone ambushed them, as long as they were in mortal danger, they could instantly escape the space.

So the only scenario where danger might arise was if the teleportation system malfunctioned. If they couldnâ€™t leave the alternate space, they would be like lambs to the slaughter when facing advanced ability users.

To make them break the glass on their own, they would either have to feel a significant threat and voluntarily leave or be subdued so Su Bei could break the glass for them.

The first option was unlikely; the second seemed more practical.

After thinking it over, Su Bei asked, â€œHow many air blocks can you create now?â€

â€œTen!â€ Mo Xiaotian answered excitedly, pleased that Su Bei had asked about something he excelled at. He was quite proud of the first ability he had developed.

Ten would be enough. Su Bei nodded. â€œIâ€™ll sneak attack from behind and drive the others away. You just need to trap one person.â€

At only 15 or 16 years old, the students werenâ€™t particularly brave, especially in a dark, ominous forest. They quickly scattered in panic, abandoning their group.

Meanwhile, Mo Xiaotian had already targeted a boy and surrounded him with several air blocks, preventing his escape.

The boy was clearly terrified and tried to call for help, but his teammates were too busy running for their own lives to bother with him.

Once the others were gone, Su Bei emerged and easily subdued the boy.

â€œItâ€™sâ€¦ itâ€™s a person!â€ The boy, restrained but oddly relieved, smiled nervously. He would much rather be eliminated by classmates than haunted by ghosts.

â€œYes, Iâ€™m human.â€ Su Bei stepped into the moonlight, letting the boy see his shadow. â€œWill you leave on your own, or should I help you?â€

Hearing this confirmation, the boy breathed a long sigh of relief. He hesitated for a moment before asking cautiously, â€œBrother, could you let me go?â€

â€œWhat do you think?â€ Su Bei asked with a faint smile.

Yeah, that wasnâ€™t happening. The boy sighed in resignation. â€œFine, Iâ€™ll leave on my own.â€

Before the boy left, Su Bei gave him a final instruction: â€œOnce youâ€™re out, go find Mr. Meng Huai from Class F and tell him that Feng Lan disappeared right after entering this space. He might be in danger.â€

â€œGot it. Youâ€™re eliminating me and still making me run errands for you? What an inspiring display of friendship.â€

Grumbling, the boy decisively broke the glass on his watch. The next moment, he disappeared into thin air.

â€œWow, thatâ€™s amazing!â€ Mo Xiaotian exclaimed, eyes wide with wonder. â€œYou can just leave like that? Breaking the glass was so easy, too! I was worried I wouldnâ€™t be able to break it if I needed to.â€

Su Beiâ€™s expression softened with a hint of relief as he nodded. â€œYeah, itâ€™s really convenient.â€

Since breaking the glass still worked to exit the alternate space, there wasnâ€™t much to worry about. Maybe he had overthought things, and the enemyâ€™s conspiracy wasnâ€™t related to this.

Waitâ€¦ somethingâ€™s wrong.

Su Beiâ€™s expression froze. Suddenly, he rememberedâ€”Feng Lan had also disappeared as soon as they entered. Who said disappearing meant returning to the academy?

And as he had considered earlier, this was only the first day of the group competition. Even if the enemy planned to make a move, wasnâ€™t it too soon? Maybe todayâ€™s teleportation system was working fine, but whoâ€™s to say it wouldnâ€™t malfunction later?

"Alright, itâ€™s better to regroup with Jiang Tianming for a long-term solution." Su Bei sighed, glanced at his watch, and said, â€œLetâ€™s go. We need to find Jiang Tianming and the others quickly. Itâ€™s already so dark, and we still donâ€™t have a place to sleep.â€

After realizing their pursuers had disappeared, Jiang Tianming and Mu Tieren stopped running. They were already exhausted after running for so long, and the night wasnâ€™t safe. If their pursuers continued chasing them, even if they felt they might lose, they would have no choice but to fight back.

Bad luck had struck Jiang Tianming earlierâ€”he ran into an opponent he had deeply offended during the individual matches. Worse yet, that opponent had teamed up with another rival for some reason, creating a group of over ten people. There was no way Jiang and Mu could win against that.

Escaping should have been easier in the dense forest, where the thick trees provided plenty of cover. However, one of the members of the pursuing teams specialized in tracking, relentlessly chasing them down.

Now that the group had given up, Jiang and Mu could finally catch their breath. But they were also curiousâ€”why did the group suddenly stop after chasing them for so long?

"Swish... Swish..."

Just as they started to rest, the sound of movement in the bushes nearby put them on high alert. Jiang Tianming and Mu Tieren exchanged wary glances, preparing to fight back.

Even though it was two against twelve, the pair, who had both ranked in the top ten during the individual matches, stood a decent chance when working together.

But to their surprise, the figures emerging from the bushes had one golden and one red head of hair.

It was Su Bei and Mo Xiaotian!

Seeing them, Jiang Tianming and Mu Tieren were caught off guard. Still, they didnâ€™t immediately let down their guard. They first checked their watches to confirm the mapâ€”sure enough, the two dots representing teammates were right next to them. Only then did they relax, knowing it really was their allies.

â€œWhy are you two here? Waitâ€”did you scare off the people chasing us?â€ Jiang Tianming blocked Mo Xiaotian, who was about to throw himself into a hug, and turned to ask Su Bei.

Su Bei nodded. â€œWe eliminated one of their members. It seems eliminating someone gives you 10 points.â€

Hearing this, Jiang Tianming glanced at the scoreboard and nodded knowingly. â€œ10 points for eliminating a person and 50 points for killing a Nightmares. It looks like completing the missions is worth more than fighting alone.â€

â€œSince there are no missions that require us to split up, we figured it would be better to regroup with you first,â€ Su Bei explained, scanning the surrounding area as he spoke. â€œMy suggestion is that we donâ€™t worry about gaining more points for the first two days and save it all for the second day.â€

Thatâ€™s why, after completing one task, he hadnâ€™t taken any further action. Even when he spotted a Nightmares from a distance, he made sure to avoid it.

This realization came after Jiang Tianming killed his first Nightmares. He suddenly noticed that his mental power was recovering much more slowly than usual.

To recover mental power, one needed to meditate quietly or sleep. While doing routine, low-energy activities could also help, the recovery rate would be much slower.

Typically, Jiang Tianming could fully recover his mental power within a day. But in this environment, it could take a day and a halfâ€”even longer if he got into any fights during that time.

After noticing the slow recovery, Jiang Tianming decided it was better to conserve his energy and act on the second day. Otherwise, heâ€™d risk becoming an easy target for others, which would be too embarrassing.

This was precisely what the academy wanted to teach them through these exercises. Real-life missions wouldnâ€™t offer the same luxuries as the academy, where ability users had ample time to recover their mental power. Students had to learn how to manage their power efficiently and maximize its usage.

Su Bei hadnâ€™t noticed this issue because his high-level mental power recovered faster and more easily, unaffected by the environment. Additionally, he had spent a large part of the day slacking off, so his energy was already mostly restored.

As for Mo Xiaotian, he hadnâ€™t said anything because he simply hadnâ€™t realized it. As a more instinct-driven fighter, Mo Xiaotian had barely used any mental power after his initial consumption upon entering the alternate space.n/Ã´/vel/b//in dot c//om

When Jiang Tianming explained his findings, both Su Bei and Mo Xiaotian had a sudden realization.

â€œRight! My mental power has also been recovering much slower! I didnâ€™t even notice until you mentioned it!â€ Mo Xiaotian exclaimed, his eyes filled with admiration.

Su Bei was equally surprised, but he quickly deduced the reason for the slow recovery. He had experienced life with regular mental power before and knew that sufficient time and a quiet environment were necessary for recovery.

He chuckled and added, â€œI hadnâ€™t noticed either. Good catch, you two.â€

Of course, the truth was that Su Bei 'had' noticedâ€”he simply wasnâ€™t affected enough for it to matter.

Jiang Tianming and Mu Tieren clearly guessed this as well. They doubted someone as meticulous as Su Bei would miss something so crucial. However, neither of them called him out on it.

Instead, Mu Tieren asked curiously, â€œIf you didnâ€™t notice the issue with mental power recovery, why did you suggest not taking action for the first two days?â€

Su Bei raised an eyebrow and smiled slyly, like a cunning fox. â€œIf the neighbors stockpile food, I stockpile weapons. The neighbors are my food supply.â€

At this point, it was already one o'clock in the morning. While teenagers their age were generally energetic and recovered quickly, and staying up late is not a big deal. But now, this was still a competition. A lack of energy would make it easy for others to sneak attack on them.

Su Bei looked around but couldnâ€™t find a particularly safe place. It took too much time to build a simple residence, and there werenâ€™t any caves in this forest area.

Sleeping directly on the ground was out of the question. The cold could seep into their bodies, making them sick, and while there werenâ€™t any large animals or birds in this area, insects were still a problem. Sleeping directly on the ground would turn them into a â€œhuman terrariumâ€ by morning. At the very least, they needed a layer of leaves for insulation.

A campfire was also necessary. Although starting a fire in the dark might attract attention, it would provide warmth and visibility and could also help against enemies.

Su Bei can be called an old hand, worked quickly and efficiently. After finishing their discussion, the others came over to help.

It was clear that Su Bei and Mu Tieren were the most skilled among them. Jiang Tianming wasnâ€™t as experienced but learned quickly. As for Mo Xiaotian, while neither skilled nor fast, he made for an excellent morale booster.

â€œOur final decision is for Xiaotian to take the first watch, followed by me, the class monitor, and lastly, you, Su Bei. Each shift is an hour and a half, and weâ€™ll all get up at 8 a.m. Does that work?â€ Jiang Tianming said while gathering leaves.

Su Bei nodded nonchalantly, understanding that they were being considerate of him. The first and last watch shifts were usually the easiest, and he accepted their arrangement without fussâ€”after all, he was the one who started the fire, so it was only fair to earn some benefits in return.

Before long, the group had finished laying out the bedding, and Su Bei had the fire going. They each took turns standing watch, as agreed.

â€œWake upâ€¦â€

Mu Tierenâ€™s voice roused Su Bei, who opened his eyes immediately, alert to his surroundings. Sleeping in a dangerous environment meant he was naturally a light sleeper.

Realizing the situation, Su Bei sat up and checked his watch. It was 6:30 a.m., right on time. He appreciated punctuality and disliked it when others let him sleep longer out of kindnessâ€”it only annoyed him.

After the shift change, Su Bei got up to stretch. While the plan was to take it easy today, based on his understanding of the competition, things were unlikely to remain peaceful.

Sure enough, by 7:30 a.m., Su Bei heard movement from above. Looking up, he spotted a pitch-black snake as thick as an adultâ€™s arm, slowly slithering down a tree near Jiang Tianming.

The snake was longâ€”so long that while its head nearly touched the ground, its tail was still hidden among the leaves. Su Bei estimated it to be at least five meters in length.

He immediately hurled a gear at it, but the snake dodged with lightning speed. Realizing it had been discovered, the snake abandoned stealth and lunged toward Jiang Tianming.

â€œWake up!â€ Su Bei shouted, running over to kick Jiang Tianming awake before delivering a flying kick that sent the snake flying.

Thankfully, he was wearing the schoolâ€™s specially-made uniform, which was highly durable. Without it, he wouldnâ€™t have dared to kick the creature directly.

â€œWhatâ€™s going on?â€ Jiang Tianming asked, following Su Beiâ€™s gaze to see the snake, now raised halfway up and glaring at them menacingly.

Mo Xiaotianâ€™s eyes widened. â€œThatâ€™s one big snake!â€

The snake hissed, its upper body swaying as it searched for the best angle to strike.

â€œItâ€™s fast,â€ Su Bei warned, his eyes sharp. â€œXiaotian, trap it!â€

â€œOn it!â€ Mo Xiaotian shouted, creating ten transparent air blocks to serve as protective barriers around the group.

Meanwhile, Mu Tieren used his extracurricular knowledge to assess the threat. â€œThis Nightmares probably isnâ€™t venomous. According to the books, venomous Nightmare Snakes have disproportionately large heads. But Iâ€™m not sure what its ability might be.â€

The lack of venom was good news, and everyone visibly relaxed. Jiang Tianming asked Su Bei for a few gears, and together they launched a coordinated attack. Keeping the saying â€œhit a snake at its seven-inch weak pointâ€ in mind, they aimed their attacks with precision.

Although the snake was fast, it couldnâ€™t dodge all their attacks, especially with Mo Xiaotianâ€™s air blocks limiting its movements. Before long, the Nightmare Snake was defeated.

Even after it fell, the group remained cautious, checking their watches to confirm they had gained the 50 points for killing the Nightmares before approaching.

Su Bei grabbed the snake by its tail and lifted it, inspecting it. â€œHow about roasted snake for breakfast?â€

Even ordinary snake meat was considered a delicacy, and Nightmare Snakes were renowned for their flavor.

Jiang Tianming couldnâ€™t help but laugh. â€œWith a snake this big, itâ€™ll probably last us through lunch too.â€

Mo Xiaotian cheered, â€œAwesome! Let me cook it! Youâ€™ll all see my grilling skills in action!â€

â€œYou know how to barbecue?â€ Mu Tieren teased with a smile. â€œNow Iâ€™m looking forward to it.â€

Jiang Tianming, who was also a skilled cook, decided to let Mo Xiaotian take the lead this time, seeing how eager he was.

As Mo Xiaotian took the snake from Su Bei's hands, the excitement on his face gradually faded, replaced by a troubled expression.

â€œWhatâ€™s wrong?â€ Mu Tieren asked considerately. â€œIs it because youâ€™ve never prepared a snake and donâ€™t know how to handle it?â€

Mo Xiaotian shook his head, looking frustrated. â€œNo, itâ€™s just... it needs to be cleaned!â€

A snake this big couldnâ€™t simply be roasted directly. At the very least, it needed to be thoroughly cleaned with river water. Using bottled water like they had done before would be wasteful.

â€œWe passed a river yesterday,â€ Jiang Tianming offered. â€œI still remember the wayâ€”itâ€™s not too far from here. Letâ€™s go together.â€

Hearing this, Mu Tieren looked surprised. â€œYou can still remember the route in this forest? I do recall seeing a river yesterday, but Iâ€™ve completely forgotten how to get there.â€

Jiang Tianming gave a faint, complicated smile, one that hinted at a story behind it. â€œYeah, remembering the way is important.â€

Sensing his tone, Mu Tieren hesitated but chose not to press further. Although they were friends, they hadnâ€™t reached the level where they could freely ask about each otherâ€™s private matters. If someone didnâ€™t want to share, it was best not to ask.

Following Jiang Tianmingâ€™s lead, they walked for half an hour before the sound of rushing water reached their ears. However, it wasnâ€™t just the sound of waterâ€”they could also hear voices.

â€œIt seems there are quite a few people near the river,â€ Su Bei remarked knowingly.

This was understandable. Water was essential for survival, and even those with little wilderness experience would instinctively set up camp near a river.

Using his mental abilities, Su Bei sensed the situation and raised an eyebrow. â€œThere are 15 people by the river, split into two groups.â€

The others werenâ€™t curious about how he knew this, and they collectively breathed a sigh of relief. Since the two groups there were coexisting peacefully, adding their team to the mix shouldnâ€™t cause any issues.

As they emerged from the forest, they were immediately met with 15 pairs of eyes. Among them, a green-haired boyâ€™s jaw dropped in surprise when he saw Su Bei. â€œItâ€™s you!â€

This was someone Su Bei had defeated in the first round of the individual battles.

Seeing a familiar face, Su Bei remained unbothered. He casually waved and greeted him, â€œOh, what a coincidence.â€

â€œCoincidence, my foot!â€ the green-haired boy shouted angrily. â€œDonâ€™t you feel even a little guilty when you see me?â€

Apparently, having been eliminated in the first round had left him resentful. After following Su Beiâ€™s subsequent matches, he realized Su Bei wasnâ€™t just reliant on trickery, as in their matchâ€”he was genuinely skilled.

Now, the green-haired boy didnâ€™t feel as humiliated about losing to Su Bei. Though Su Bei was from Class F, his abilities clearly exceeded that rank. Losing to a Class F student was embarrassing, but losing to someone in the top 10 was not.

Still, the question lingered in his mind: why had Su Bei resorted to trickery in their match instead of using his true strength to secure a convincing win? It felt like mockery.

â€œYou clearly couldâ€™ve beaten me outright, but instead, you chose to humiliate me,â€ the green-haired boy said, his voice tinged with both anger and hurt.

Su Bei: â€œ...â€

Was it possible that he really had no other option at the time?

Unfortunately, he couldnâ€™t explain the truth, leaving the green-haired boy none the wiser. Su Bei sighed inwardly, ignored the accusations, and crouched by the riverbank. Looking at Mo Xiaotian, he said, â€œWhat are you standing around for? Come clean the snake!â€

â€œOh, right!â€ Mo Xiaotian snapped out of his daze, hurriedly carrying the giant snake over and starting to clean and prepare it.

The massive snake drew everyoneâ€™s attention, and those by the river couldnâ€™t help but gulp. The green-haired boy stared at the Nightmare Snake, then back at Su Bei, his expression filled with disbelief. â€œDid you kill this?â€

â€œIt was a team effort,â€ Su Bei replied modestly.

Even so, his words were enough to leave the others stunned. While they could only flee from Nightmares, Su Beiâ€™s teamâ€”comprised mostly of Class F studentsâ€”had managed to kill one. It was incredible.

Realizing he had just been berating someone so powerful, the green-haired boy suddenly felt small. Clearing his throat, he said awkwardly, â€œAhem, well, uh... youâ€™re impressive. Letâ€™s forget about what happened before.â€

Having said that, he smugly thought he had both ensured his safety and saved face. However, his companions looked at him with disdain and quietly stepped away, for fear others would associate them with this guy.
